p: Tick-borne encephalitis virus is found in many areas throughout Europe and Asia. Transmission to humans is mainly through tick bites but can occasionally result from consumption of unpasteurized milk [ 175]. LIV is endemic within upland areas in the UK, particularly in Scotland, Wales, the northwest and southwest of England [ 169]. There have also been reports of LIV in Ireland and Norway [ 176]. Sheep infected with SSEV have been reported from the Basque region of Spain [ 174, 177]. The first isolation of GGEV was made in the village of Vergina in northern Greece [ 178]. Subsequent studies have suggested that GGEV circulates in the I. ricinus population in northern Greece, although at low density [ 179]. TTEV was first reported from northwestern Turkey (Anatolia) as encephalitis in sheep and was subsequent confirmed by nucleotide analysis to be related to tick-borne encephalitis virus [ 180â€“ 182].
